prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mrk 463: CO (2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dense, molecular gas is the fuel for star formation and potentially for black hole growth. Hence, we propose to obtain ALMA observations of Mrk 463 using the CO(2-1) emission line as a tracer for cold molecular gas, and CS(5-4) as a tracer of dense environments. This high resolution (<1 kpc for all the galaxies in our sample) is required in order to map the distribution of gas in the regions surrounding the two black holes.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Receiver(s): Band 6 (spectral lines CO (2-1), CS (5-4) plus continuum ~221 GHz), Our primary goal is to map the distribution and kinematics of CO (2-1), however in order to maximize scientific output we also include continuum and the dense molecular gas tracer CS (5-4).
Angular Resolution: ~0.2” and 0.25" at Band 6 in order to resolve structures of ~100-200 pc. The ACA is not needed for these observations.
Spectral Resolution: FDM mode with spectral averaging of 16 for a total bandwidth of 4x1875 MHz and a resolution of 7.813 MHz. This setup gives the same data rates as TDM though with a factor of 4 better resolution (~10 km/s versus 40 km/s).
Band 6 Sensitivity: The sensitivity is calculated by taking the total integrated flux density (in Jy km/s) and making several corrections. First, we must make corrections based on the nuclear CO distribution and contribution to the total flux. In order to ensure that we detect both nuclei we assume a 2:1 light ratio (divide by 3) as supported by observations of other dual AGN (e.g., Koss et al. 2011, Tacconi et al. 1999 and Greve et al. 2009). We also must estimate over how many beams the flux is spread. Then we divide by the line width in km/s. If we use CO J:1-0 measurements as a proxy for CO J:2-1 we correct by a factor of 3; as estimated for the prototypical dual AGN, NGC 6240, by Casoli et al. 1992 and Greve et al. 2009. Finally, in order to detect a CO J:2-1 line at a sufficient S/N across the entire width of the line, including the wings, we divide by a S/N of 10 (or greater) to achieve a sensitivity in mJy/beam.
Mrk 463: The upper flux density limit of the nuclei that was undetected in Mrk 463 as given by Evans et al. (2002) is 2.7 Jy km/s. We estimate that for the 0.2" resolution (~200 pc) the light will fall in no more than 7 beams (Fathi et al. 2013). The line width is 200 km/s (Evans et al. 2011). The estimated sensitivity is 0.58 mJy/beam. The time on source is 50.64 minutes and the total time requested is 2.04 hours.
Band 6 Observing Time: For Band 6, the ALMA sensitivity calculator, assuming thirty-four 12-m antennas and dual polarization, predicts ~5 hours integration total, to reach a 1 sigma = 0.58, 0.88, 0.79 and 0.845 mJy in the channel for each target (Mrk 463, Mrk 739, ESO 509 and 2MASX J16311, respectively). The time on source is 50.64, 23.33, 23.59, and 23.34 minutes respectively. The total time requested for each target is 2.04, 1.0, 1.01 and 1.0 hours respectively. Our overheads are ~25% of the total time requested, which is within the limit (<30%) suggested in the ALMA Cycle 2 Proposer's Guide.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Major galaxy mergers are particularly important for galaxy evolution as they can funnel fuel (gas) into the center of the galaxy triggering both star formation and an active galactic nuclei (AGN). Thus, as a natural consequence, systems with 2+ accreting supermassive black holes (SMBHs) `caught in the act' of merging represent a critical stage in the evolution of a galaxy. Only a few, 13, such dual AGN are known. The properties of the gas in these systems will offer critical clues to the external and internal conditions under which both SMBHs can be activated during these encounters and their influence on the host galaxies. We propose an ALMA study aimed at attaining new understanding of SMBH and host galaxy growth at a critical stage in the merger process: near coalescence. Specifically, we will map at high spatial resolution, ~100 pc, the molecular gas distribution and its kinematics in all 4 merging galaxies for which this is possible given the current ALMA capabilities. These observations will prove instrumental in determining the conditions which are conducive to simultaneous growth of both SMBHs as well as its effect on the host galaxies.
